Replace Instances with Code
LIFE402
Notes
This module is due to commence in June 2017

Overview

Overview
Skill/Other Attribute 1:
"
Problem solving/ critical thinking/ creativity analysing facts and situations and applying creative thinking to develop appropriate solutions.
"
How this is developed:
"Self-directed learning"
Educational Aims
To provide an explanation of current understanding of cancer development and progression, and how this is exploited in the rational design of drugs to target cancer;

To explain the latest knowledge of the molecular mechanisms of anti-cancer drugs and the potential for side-effects and drug resistance;

To critically evaluate the clinical effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of modern cancer drugs.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The aim of this module is to provide an understanding of cancer development and progression and how this is exploited in the rational design of drugs to target cancer. A further aim is to explain the molecular mechanism of anti-cancer drugs and the potential for side-effects, drug toxicity and drug resistance. The module will be assessed by aÂ summative exercise and by a final examination.
Outline Syllabus
Introduction to cancer: hallmarks of cancer, the aetiology of cancer and cancer treatment, cancer research careers;

Cancer chemotherapy and drug resistance;

Kinase inhibitors and cancer treatment;

Hormone regulated cancer: Oestrogen, progesterone and androgen receptors, and drugs modulating these receptors;

Angiogenesis and tumour hypoxia and the development of anti-angiogenic drugs;

Cancer immunotherapy and the development of therapeutic monoclonal antibodies.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching method 1: Asynchronous online lecture material with follow up synchronous face to face or online tutorial/question and answer discussion sessions.

Implementation of the hybrid model of teaching and assessment, in compliance with the âHigher Level Principles for Learning, Teaching and Assessment 2020-21â.

The course has been structured so that the content, where possible, will be released as short pre-recorded âconceptâ video explanations broken down into topics that would normally be covered in a synchronous lecture. Due to the number of students on this and the sister LIFE402 course, this asynchronous content will be released on a Monday afternoon. On the Friday of the following week, 3 x 1 hr F2F tutorials will be run (on campus); one of these sessions will be via zoom for students not able to attend face to face. These sessions will require the students to book one of the available slots in the lecture theatre. The lecturer who provided the course content released that week will then be available to answer questions emailed to the lecturer prior to the session, or to take some limited spontaneous questions. In addition, there will be some zoom revision sessions for all students to attend.
In addition, there will be some zoom revision sessions for all students to attend.

Teaching method 2: Self-directed learning aided by directed reading and formative questions

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Assessment 1 will be a 1500 word written assignment. This will be worth 40% and occur following the first cycle of teaching in week 6 or 8.

Assessment 2 will be a 2000 word written assignment. This will be worth 60% and occur at the end of the course.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Overview

Overview
Skill/Other Attribute 1:
"
Problem solving/ critical thinking/ creativity analysing facts and situations and applying creative thinking to develop appropriate solutions.
"
How this is developed:
"Self-directed learning"
Educational Aims
To provide an explanation of current understanding of cancer development and progression, and how this is exploited in the rational design of drugs to target cancer;

To explain the latest knowledge of the molecular mechanisms of anti-cancer drugs and the potential for side-effects and drug resistance;

To critically evaluate the clinical effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of modern cancer drugs.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The aim of this module is to provide an understanding of cancer development and progression and how this is exploited in the rational design of drugs to target cancer. A further aim is to explain the molecular mechanism of anti-cancer drugs and the potential for side-effects, drug toxicity and drug resistance. The module will be assessed by aÂ summative exercise and by a final examination.
Outline Syllabus
Introduction to cancer: hallmarks of cancer, the aetiology of cancer and cancer treatment, cancer research careers;

Cancer chemotherapy and drug resistance;

Kinase inhibitors and cancer treatment;

Hormone regulated cancer: Oestrogen, progesterone and androgen receptors, and drugs modulating these receptors;

Angiogenesis and tumour hypoxia and the development of anti-angiogenic drugs;

Cancer immunotherapy and the development of therapeutic monoclonal antibodies.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching method 1: Asynchronous online lecture material with follow up synchronous face to face or online tutorial/question and answer discussion sessions.

Implementation of the hybrid model of teaching and assessment, in compliance with the âHigher Level Principles for Learning, Teaching and Assessment 2020-21â.

The course has been structured so that the content, where possible, will be released as short pre-recorded âconceptâ video explanations broken down into topics that would normally be covered in a synchronous lecture. Due to the number of students on this and the sister LIFE402 course, this asynchronous content will be released on a Monday afternoon. On the Friday of the following week, 3 x 1 hr F2F tutorials will be run (on campus); one of these sessions will be via zoom for students not able to attend face to face. These sessions will require the students to book one of the available slots in the lecture theatre. The lecturer who provided the course content released that week will then be available to answer questions emailed to the lecturer prior to the session, or to take some limited spontaneous questions. In addition, there will be some zoom revision sessions for all students to attend.
In addition, there will be some zoom revision sessions for all students to attend.

Teaching method 2: Self-directed learning aided by directed reading and formative questions

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Assessment 1 will be a 1500 word written assignment. This will be worth 40% and occur following the first cycle of teaching in week 6 or 8.

Assessment 2 will be a 2000 word written assignment. This will be worth 60% and occur at the end of the course.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
